awd_titl_txt: Data-Driven Many-Body Models for Molecular Simulations of Ions in Water:  From Ionic Clusters to Concentrated Electrolyte Solutions
awd_abstract_narration:
Dr. Francesco Paesani of the University of California-San Diego is supported by an award from the Chemical Theory, Models and Computational Methods program in the Division of Chemistry. A quantitative, molecular-level characterization of the structural, thermodynamic, dynamical, and spectroscopic properties of ions in aqueous environments under different conditions is key to understanding several fundamental processes, including ion-molecule reactions and ion-induced nucleation in the atmosphere, acid-base reactions in solution, ion transport in biological channels, and multiphase processes at air/liquid and solid/liquid interfaces. A unified picture of the behavior of hydrated ions across different phases and in different environments is particularly challenging, requiring a quantitative assessment of competing enthalpic and entropic effects associated with the interplay between ion–ion, ion–water, and water–water interactions, which are further modulated by nuclear quantum effects. 

By combining data-driven many-body potential energy functions derived entirely from high-level ab initio reference data with both classical and quantum molecular dynamics, Paesani will extend his many-body molecular dynamics (MB-MD) methodology to the modeling of ions in water, from gas-phase clusters to bulk solutions. The MB-MD methodology provides an accurate, yet efficient, theoretical/computational framework for molecular simulations of aqueous systems with high accuracy and predictive power. In this research project Paesani aims to develop a microscopic understanding of single-ion hydration structure and thermodynamics from small gas-phase clusters to bulk solutions in terms of individual many-body contributions, determine single-ion hydration free energies and ion–ion association free energies and decompose them in terms of elementary ion–water and water–water many-body effects, and characterize water hydrogen-bond structure and dynamics in electrolyte solutions as a function of ion concentration and composition, disentangling ion–ion, ion–water and water–water contributions. The theoretical/ computational methodology developed as part of the proposed research will have broad impact on a wide range of user communities from chemistry to materials science and biology, and will involve the training and education of high school, undergraduate and graduate students who will acquire a solid foundation in theoretical, computational, and physical chemistry. The interdisciplinary nature of the proposed project will provide the students with the opportunity to work at the interface of different disciplines which will prepare them for a wide range of careers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The main goal of our research was to extend the data-driven many-body formalism to model ions in water, spanning from gas-phase clusters to bulk solutions. This research aimed to achieve a detailed molecular-level characterization of the structural, thermodynamic, dynamical, and spectroscopic properties of ions in aqueous environments under various conditions. Understanding these properties is crucial for numerous fundamental processes, including ion-molecule reactions, ion-induced nucleation in the atmosphere, acid-base reactions in solution, ion transport in biological channels, and multiphase processes at air/liquid and solid/liquid interfaces.

Over the course of this project, we developed a general methodology to generate data-driven many-body potential energy functions (PEFs) for charged ionic species. By integrating machine learning-based approaches for selecting molecular configurations with our data-driven many-body energy (MB-nrg) formalism, we created MB-nrg PEFs for various ion-water systems. These PEFs were then utilized in classical molecular dynamics (MD) and path-integral molecular dynamics (PIMD) simulations to investigate the hydration properties of ions in water.

One of our significant accomplishments was demonstrating the necessity of representing short-range many-body effects explicitly for an accurate description of hydration structures. Using MD and PIMD simulations for halide and alkali-metal ions in solution, we quantified the interplay between many-body and nuclear quantum effects on the local hydration structure. 

We also developed a deeper understanding of ion hydration by analyzing individual many-body contributions to the interactions between ions and water molecules. This analysis allowed us to develop robust and transferable PEFs for ions in water, achieving the same accuracy as experimental measurements in both gas and liquid phases. Simulations with our MB-nrg PEFs provided quantitative agreement with experimental data and showed that both point-charge and polarizable force fields commonly used in ion hydration simulations are inadequate and often misleading. These results confirmed that our MB-nrg PEFs are capable of accurately predicting the properties of ionic aqueous systems across different phases.

In addition to our research on ions, we introduced the MB-pol(2023) PEFs, a new family of data-driven many-body PEFs for water. These PEFs, using larger training sets and sophisticated machine-learned representations, achieve sub-chemical accuracy in modeling the isomers of the water hexamer and show remarkable agreement with experimental results for various properties of liquid water, surpassing previous models.

Our research efforts also led to the development of a theoretical/computational framework for generating data-driven many-body potentials from density functional theory (DFT) reference data, termed MB-DFT. This framework enables efficient many-body MD simulations while maintaining DFT accuracy. We addressed challenges such as delocalization error and potential elevation of DFT and MB-DFT to near-chemical accuracy through a density-corrected formalism.

To facilitate the broader application of our methods, we released our MB-Fit and MBX software. MB-Fit allows users to develop many-body MB-nrg PEFs for generic molecules, while MBX supports classical and quantum molecular simulations, as well as hybrid simulations combining conventional force fields with MB-pol/MB-nrg PEFs. Both software packages are open-source and publicly available, enabling researchers worldwide to utilize our advanced simulation tools.

Besides these scientific achievements, our project also provided unique training opportunities to several undergraduate and graduate students as well as postdoctoral scholars. All team members were trained in broader aspects of computational sciences, including sustainable software engineering best practices for multi-core and many-core computer architectures, and numerical simulations on workstations, high-performance computing clusters, and supercomputers. Additionally, they received specialized training in theoretical chemistry, computer science, and data science, including quantum chemistry, molecular simulations, and machine learning.

Overall, our project significantly advanced the understanding and simulation of ion-water interactions, providing a robust foundation for future research in computational chemistry and molecular dynamics. Our findings and tools will contribute to a wide range of scientific fields, from atmospheric chemistry to biophysics, enhancing our ability to model and understand complex aqueous systems.
